Not as much work but clearly no structure in the course. Tests had unreasonable expectations given the lack of flow in the lectures. Also, a final paper, final presentation, and final test is too much. Professor should follow the pick 2 from 3 criteria for the final of these three. This would follow that the two final assignments would be of a higher quality as students would not spread themselves too thin.

The course is more oriented at practical risk-assessments rather than the theoretical framework, which could be either a strength or a weakness, depending on the student. For me it was a weakness.

And perhaps because this course is a bit outside my field, I found it a bit of a challenge to determine the boundaries of each domain--but I think this may be due also to changes in the field and different agencies.

Additional resources that might be helpful:
NRC (National Research Council). (2009). Science and decisions: advancing risk assessment. National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/12209.
Risk assessments and management theory and sociology (Sunstein, Beck, Giddens, Hacking, etc.)

Material had potential to be very interesting, but the lectures are so unstructured and the professor often goes on unnecessary tangents. Expectations for exams and group papers/presentations remained relatively unclear until the very last minute. Honestly not a great class for non-EHS students, as the professor seems to expect for you to have a basic foundation in areas like toxicology that would be pretty foreign for non-EHS students.
Great content. More discussion can engage students
He is very knowledgeable about the course material, but was not always clear in his expectations of students.

Good guy but fails to recognize this material is not as easily digestible and He tends to quickly go over some crucial aspects. His expectations are quite hope and I hope he can make this course more accessible next year.
Hard to follow along because the lecturing style isn't structured. He is a nice person though
I appreciate his passion for the topic! I really enjoyed the lectures. However, he was consistently late for class.

Professor Ginsberg was good, well-versed in the field.

Because of the field-specific terminology, I think his slides could be improved to better define the domains and steps. I believe he can follow them quite easily, but in preparing for exams, I found myself a bit confused on where I was in each step.

Dr. Ginsberg is clearly an expert in this subject matter and field, but I did not get the sense that he cared much for the class. He was 15-20 minutes late to class almost every week. I understand that he's driving from NY, but being late was more normal than not, so if he cared about the course, I would have liked for him to prioritize finding a solution so that he can get to class on time (and then he would keep us late to make up for time lost - not ideal for 5pm on a Friday). He also should not come in to teach this course expecting all of his students to be well-versed in toxicology like he is. Rarely followed the syllabus.
